item.title: In Honor of Mario's 40th Anniversary, Here Are 5 Mario Co-Op Games To Play This Weekend
item.description:
September 13, 2025, marks the 40th anniversary of the Super Mario Bros. franchise. Why not celebrate this landmark date with some Mario co-op this weekend? Jump into a classic arcade title with Mario, Luigi, and their friends (and enemies), or explore some of the newer offerings currently available on the Nintendo Switch and Nintendo Switch 2. There's Mario-themed co-op games out there in practically every genre, from adventure to platforming to sports, kart racing and more, so there's definitely something for everyone.

Mario Kart World

One of the newest co-op titles starring Mario and co., Mario Kart World debuted alongside the launch of the Nintendo Switch 2 console earlier in 2025. Players can challenge one another to races across a variety of tracks or simply hang out in Free Roam mode, which offers a massive world to explore. Plus, there are tons of exciting speed- and technique-based challenges to find around the world. There's no better way to celebrate Mario's anniversary than with a race — or two, or three, or even more. Just don't forget to pick up a delicious snack along the way at one of the many drive-up restaurants available around the game's world.

Super Mario Bros. Wonder

The September 12, 2025, Nintendo Direct broadcast revealed that Super Mario Bros. Wonder will be getting a Switch 2 edition complete with new content, including a multiplayer-focused area called Bellabel Park. Unfortunately, the updated Switch 2 edition of the game won't be coming out until Spring 2026, but that doesn't mean that players can't enjoy some Wonder-ful co-op together this weekend. Explore the colorful and exciting new kingdom and all the strange effects its levels feature while playing Super Mario Bros. Wonder with friends and family.

Super Mario Bros. 3

No Mario co-op weekend would be complete without a blast from the past in the form of a classic multiplayer Mario experience. While there have been many games over the years that see two players teaming up to control Mario and Luigi, Super Mario Bros. 3 is consistently hailed as one of the best. It introduced several now-iconic elements of the Mario franchise, such as an overworld map, and saw the debut of recurring enemies like the Koopalings. Any of the classic Mario games are great for a nostalgic co-op throwback, but Super Mario Bros. 3 does it best.

Mario Tennis Aces

It's great playing collaborative co-op with a friend or family member — but it's also great to challenge them to a friendly (or not-so-friendly) sports match. Players can let their competitive sides loose in the many Mario-centric sports games released throughout the year. But, as the Mario Tennis series will be returning soon with a new title, Mario Tennis Fever, for the Nintendo Switch 2, players could spend this weekend brushing up on their tennis skills in the previous title, Mario Tennis Aces. Fever is going to spice up tennis gameplay with new moves, rackets with a wide variety of unique effects, and an all-new Adventure mode, so interested players should definitely get some Mario Tennis practice in before the game releases.

Finally, players can finish off a weekend filled with Mario-themed co-op experiences by creating their own levels in Super Mario Maker 2. Players can work together with friends and family to design levels collaboratively, or they can create levels on their own and then challenge one another to complete them. There's no better way to celebrate 40 years of fun and games with Mario and co. than by being creative and sharing that creativity with one another, and making levels in Super Mario Maker 2 is an awesome way to do that.

item.title: Dynasty Warriors: Origins Confirmed for Nintendo Switch 2
item.description:
Dynasty Warriors: Origins will land on the Nintendo Switch 2 on January 22, 2026, Nintendo confirmed during its September 12 Direct. It was a busy presentation, with Nintendo releasing a flurry of announcements, from new game reveals to surprise third-party titles coming to the company's consoles. Amid all the excitement was some good news for Musou fans, who can now look forward to playing Dynasty Warriors: Origins on the Switch 2.

While the Dynasty Warriors franchise has gone through a bit of a drought over the past few years, Koei Tecmo and Omega Force gave it new life with the latest entry in early 2025. In less than a month after release, Dynasty Warriors: Origins sold over one million copies, with its free demo exceeding two million downloads in the same time frame. Now, the company is looking to keep that success rolling by bringing the title to another platform in the near future.

Dynasty Warriors: Origins and Its DLC Are Coming to Switch 2 in January 2026

Dynasty Warriors: Origins ' Switch 2 announcement trailer aired during the latest Nintendo Direct, revealing that the game will come to the console on January 22, 2026. That places it roughly one year after Dynasty Warriors: Origins' January 2025 release on PC, Xbox Series X/S, and PlayStation 5, and the core game itself is not the only thing fans have to look forward to on that day. The trailer also revealed that the previously announced paid DLC for the title will be available for all platforms at the same time that Origins comes to Switch 2.

item.title: Destiny 2: Xur Exotic Armor, Weapon, and Recommendations for September 12
item.description:
Xur has returned again to Destiny 2 , complete with new exotic and legendary gear for players to check out for a limited time. It's been an up and down week for many fans at the usual weekly reset. Bungie revealed more details for the upcoming Destiny 2 expansion known as Renegades, which adds its own Star Wars-inspired flavor to the world thanks to a collaboration with LucasFilm Games.

However, for as much excitement as that garnered, the accompanying Ash & Iron update for Destiny 2 seemingly fell flat for many. Bugs and other issues hampered players inside of the new Territories: Reclaim activity, while problems with the power leveling system seemingly remained in place. Bungie has outlined plans to fix these issues, with a new update coming at reset next week, though the situation has continued to frustrate the player base.

For now, though, the weekend merchant Xur is back with a new inventory of gear for Destiny 2 players. Follow this guide for his current weekend location, news on his exotic cipher quest, as well as a review of all the exotic and legendary gear he's brought for the weekend of September 12, 2025.

Where is Xur?

Xur has now taken up permanent residence in the Bazaar area inside The Tower, so there's no need to hunt for the merchant around the solar system anymore.

Since the Bazaar is located between both fast travel points, players can pick either one to load into. Head into the area where Ikora and Hawthorne are and look for the Ramen Shop towards the back wall. While facing the shop, the alley is to the right, where Xur is standing.

item.title: Borderlands 4: How to Escape the No-Escape Room
item.description:
Within Borderlands 4 's Terminus District of Dominion, players can find advertisements for the No Escape Room, a thrilling activity that will see those who fail die here. With the Smiley Man greeting players to their salvation or certain doom, it's time to figure out a way out from the No Escape Room without using Fast Travel to complete the quest and prove that this Vault Hunter has what it takes. Below is the solution for each of the escape rooms present in the No-Escape Room side mission for Borderlands 4 .

How to Open the Chests in the Correct Order in the No-Escape Room

The correct door to open is the yellow door , noted for being the furthest right door, and the one that lacks any corpses or blood beside it. Opening the yellow door will allow players to proceed to the next room, where they can look up to use a grapple hook point to enter the 2nd room.

How to Find the Correct Key Order in the No-Escape Room

The 2nd room of the No Escape Room has players search for a key in a box, to open yet another box with a key, and so on. There are 5 boxes, each noted for a unique symbol, and players must open each box in a very specific order. Players can, in fact, find the hints required by looking around the room for cardboard signs that show the correct order, but we've shown the solution in the image above, and will detail the solution below:

  • Open the 2nd chest, noted for the trinity circles
  • Open the 5th chest, noted for the bird drawing
  • Open the 4th chest, noted for the cow drawing
  • Open the 1st chest, noted for being a triangle
  • Open the 3rd chest, noted for being an eyeball

How to Escape the Maze in the No-Escape Room

Once players drop down into the maze, they will want to follow the carrots that are found on the floor to find the exit . These carrots lead players to the exit of the maze, but be warned, some of the path is blocked by fire, so simply walk through and prepare to use a Repkit to heal. The video above showcases the route we took for the maze, but here are some directions players will want to take from the start:

After exiting the maze, Smiley Man will place the Vault Hunters in a kill box. To escape, look to the right and use the grapple hook to open a vent, where you can shoot the powered device to deactivate the force field and gas. Smiley Man will then open a door and walk through, but do not follow him, as this room is an incinerator that will kill you. Instead, look to the left of this door to find the escape door.

item.title: Pokemon Pokopia Would Feel Incomplete Without These 5 Stardew Valley Features
item.description:
One of the more unexpected announcements during September 12's Nintendo Direct broadcast, Pokemon Pokopia brings cozy farming and life simulator elements to the world of Pokemon . In Pokemon Pokopia, players take on the role of a Ditto who is able to mimic human form. They bond with a variety of Pokemon and work together with them to harvest crops, build structures, craft items, and more. Pokemon's venture into the farming simulator genre should ideally take a few nods from Stardew Valley by including these features.

An Affection System For Pokemon

Stardew Valley features both an affection system for residents of Pelican Town and one for animals raised on the player's farm. Ideally, a hypothetical affection system in Pokemon Pokopia should be a mix of the two. The Ditto should be able to pet Pokemon and feed them their favorite foods, but also give them gifts and spend time with them to get to know them better, especially as the protagonist is capable of speaking the language of Pokemon unlike a standard Trainer.

A Dungeon Or Other Area For Combat And Exploration

While the farming simulator genre is all about farming, most good farming sims also feature an area where players can fight, look for treasure, and have a more traditional adventure. In Stardew Valley, players can explore the Mines and later the Skull Cavern to find all sorts of treasure and fight against a variety of monsters. Given its Pokemon roots, Pokopia should definitely include something similar — perhaps a dungeon in homage to the Pokemon Mystery Dungeon games. Maybe Ditto will even be able to gather a party of Pokemon allies to go exploring for resources and treasure?

In-Depth Cooking System With Different Meal Effects

Food and cooking have been a big part of the Pokemon series for a long time, and have seen a greater emphasis in recent games such as Sword and Shield's curry-making and Scarlet and Violet's picnics. Pokopia should draw on that and include a cooking feature where players can make meals with different effects that can help them perform their farming and crafting tasks. Berries, a staple of the Pokemon series since the beginning, could form the core ingredients, although some of the sandwich fillings from Paldea or Galarian curries would be a fun inclusion as well.

Some Form Of Fishing Mini-Game

Farming and fishing go hand-in-hand - from Stardew Valley to Rune Factory, most games in the genre have a fishing mini-game of some kind. And, with a wide range of Water Pokemon available to help out, fishing seems like an absolutely natural addition to Pokemon Pokopia. Perhaps the Ditto protagonist will have to fish for Pokemon such as Magikarp and Feebas before they are willing to help out. Alternately, they could fish for treasure like pearls or non-Pokemon cooking ingredients like seaweed, with the help of Water-type Pokemon of course.

A Seasonal Cycle And Limited-Time Events

Most games in the cozy life simulator genre regularly offer limited-time events and festivals for players to participate in. Animal Crossing 's were based around the real world calendar, while Stardew Valley used in-game seasons. Pokopia could see Ditto and their friends celebrating events throughout the 'year,' such as festivals honoring a specific type of Pokemon or region.

The inclusion of a seasonal calendar in the game could allow for a focus on Pokemon with different forms, like Deerling or Castform. The latter could even potentially help Ditto control the weather or cause the occasional rainstorm that automatically waters crops. Both a real-time calendar like Animal Crossing or an in-game one like Stardew Valley could work, although the latter might allow players to find and recruit a large variety of Pokemon more quickly.
